newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian oil imports seen rising to $13 bln in 5 yrs.
newsitem.headline: Indian oil imports seen rising to $13 bln in 5 yrs.

text.p: India's petroleum products imports are poised to jump to $13 billion in the next five years, the central bank governor said on Thursday.

"Allowing for a moderate firming up of international prices and the distinct shift in the pattern of imports in favour of products, the POL (petroleum, oil and lubricants) import bill can be expected to go up from $7.5 billion in 1995/96 (April-March) to $13.0 billion by 2000/01," Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Chakravarty Rangarajan said.
He was addressing a meeting of business leaders in New Delhi.
"This would imply that over the medium term the share of POL imports would average around 17 percent," Rangarajan said.
While this is sustainable and would not impose undue pressure on the balance of payment, it is important to ensure that POL imports are contained within this prudent limit."
"Over the medium term, an energy plan which takes into account conservation and inter-fuel substitution possibilities should be drawn up," he added.
